events.description: Horst Köhler served as the President of Germany, focusing on domestic and foreign policy issues.
supporting_quotes: During his presidency, Köhler gained a reputation for regularly voicing his opinion on foreign policy matters.
Throughout his six years as president, Köhler 'worked hard to put Africa on the top of Germany's political agenda', according to Deutsche Welle.

events.description: Köhler launched the Partnership with Africa initiative to foster dialogue between African and European leaders, entrepreneurs, intellectuals, and students.
supporting_quotes: One of his trademark projects was the Partnership with Africa initiative, which brought together heads of state, entrepreneurs, intellectuals and students from Africa and Europe to create a 'dialogue of equals'.

events.description: Köhler presented his book 'Schicksal Afrika' on the eve of his resignation, featuring contributions from notable figures.
supporting_quotes: On the eve of his resignation, Köhler presented his book Schicksal Afrika, an edited volume on the continent's future with contributions from 41 authors, including former African presidents Thabo Mbeki and John Kufuor as well as Nobel Prize Literature Laureate Wole Soyinka.

events.description: Köhler dissolved the Bundestag at Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's request in July 2005.
supporting_quotes: In July 2005, he dissolved the Bundestag at Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's request, after the latter had lost a motion of confidence.

events.description: Horst Köhler served as the President of Germany, making significant decisions such as vetoing bills and addressing the nation.
supporting_quotes: In October 2006, Köhler made a far-reaching decision by vetoing the bill which would transfer Germany's Air Safety Administration into private ownership.
In December 2006 he did not sign the Consumer Information Law
In March 2007, Köhler turned down a politically contentious request for clemency by Christian Klar
In his 2007 Christmas address to the nation, Köhler urged the government to push ahead more quickly with reforms.
On 22 May 2008, Köhler announced his candidacy for a second term as president.
On 23 May 2009, he was re-elected by the Federal Assembly
On 31 May 2010, Köhler announced his resignation as President of Germany.

events.description: Concerned with preserving and creating new sustainable jobs, improving the education system, and addressing demographic change.
supporting_quotes: as the ninth President of the Federal Republic of Germany. In the domestic arena, the Federal President was concerned above all with preserving and creating new sustainable jobs.
On 31 May 2010, Horst Köhler resigned from his office of Federal President.

events.description: Exercised ceremonial powers, including dissolving parliament in 2005 and moving national elections forward. Reelected in 2009 but resigned in 2010 following controversial remarks.
supporting_quotes: German president is largely a ceremonial one, Köhler exercised what power he did have, as when, in 2005, he followed Chancellor Schröder’s proposal to dissolve the parliament and move national elections up by a year.
He was reelected in 2009 by a single vote.

During a radio interview in May 2010, Köhler stated that some German military deployments, such as the mission in Afghanistan, were to protect the country’s economic interests. The remarks proved controversial, and he resigned shortly thereafter.

events.description: Appointed by UN Secretary-General António Guterres to mediate in the disputed region of Western Sahara. Stepped down in 2019 due to health reasons.
supporting_quotes: In 2017 UN Secretary-General António Guterres named Köhler his personal envoy to Western Sahara, a disputed region in Africa.
Two years later Köhler stepped down from the post, citing health reasons.
